description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett beslut om stöd till Världsbanken för projektet "Uganda Reproductive, Maternal, Child Health Services Improvement Project". Ambassaden föreslår ett stöd på 250 miljoner kronor över en femårsperiod, från 2017 till 2021. Projektets längd är fyra år och sex månader, med en sammanlagd budget på cirka 165 miljoner USD inklusive det svenska bidraget. Av den totala projektbudgeten på 165 miljoner USD tillhandahålls 110 miljoner USD genom lån från Världsbanken (IDA) och 30 miljoner USD från Global Financing Facility – GFF Trust Fund. Projektet förväntas börja i juni 2017.
I juli 2015 valdes Uganda tillsammans med sju andra länder ut att stödjas under GFF. GFF är ett nationellt drivet partnerskap kopplat till initiativet "Every Woman Every Child", som syftar till att minska mödra- och barnadödlighet och förbättra mödrars, nyföddas, barns och ungdomars hälsa och livskvalitet genom ett integrerat hälsosystem och evidensbaserade lösningar. Inom ramen för GFF har regeringen reviderat Ugandas "Reproductive Maternal Newborn Child Adolescent Health - RMNCAH Sharpened Plan" (2016-20). Sharpened Plan redogör för prioriterade insatser och identifierar viktiga brister kopplat till RMNCAH i Uganda.
Världsbankens "Uganda Reproductive, Maternal, Child Health Services Improvement Project" implementeras av hälsovårdsministeriet i Uganda (Ministry of Health - MoH) och bidrar direkt till de uppsatta målen i RMNCAH Sharpened Plan 2016-2020. Projektet syftar till att förbättra kvalitén på sjukvården, tillgång till och utnyttjande av hälsovårdstjänster kopplat till RMNCAH samt födelse- och dödsregistrering i utvalda distrikt i Uganda. De övergripande projektmålen är som följer:
A) Förbättrad användning av prioriterade hälso- och sjukvårdstjänster med fokus på reproduktiv, mödra, barn- och ungdomshälsa i de utvalda distrikten
B) Nationell implementering av födelse- och dödsregistrering
Projektet består av fyra olika komponenter:
Komponent 1: Resultatbaserad finansiering (RBF) för primärvårdstjänster (IDA 43 MUSD, GFF 25 MUSD, svensk finansiering 17,5 MUSD) Komponent 2: Hälsosystemstärkande aktiviteter med fokus på RMNCAH (IDA 54,5 MUSD, svensk finansiering 7,5 MUSD) Komponent 3: Stärkt kapacitet vad gäller födelse- och dödsregistrering (IDA 5 MUSD, GFF 5 MUSD) Komponent 4: Förbättrad institutionell kapacitet för att hantera projektaktiviteter (IDA 7,5 MUSD)
Det specifika målet för komponent 1, som står för den största delen av projektbudgeten, är att skala upp och institutionalisera RBF med fokus på RMNCAH-tjänster. RBF-paketet består av RMNCAH-insatser i primärvården (hälsocenter-nivå III och IV) inklusive uppsökande hälsoarbete genom s.k. Village Health Teams (VHT). Den resultatbaserade finansieringen innefattar mödravårdsbesök, säkra förlossningar, akut obstetrisk vård, spädbarnsvård, postabort vård, tillgång till preventivmedel och uppsökande RMNCAH verksamhet inklusive nutrition, förebyggande och behandling av vanligt förekommande barnsjukdomar och tillhandahållande av ungdomshälsovård. RBF-betalningar kommer att göras gentemot verifierade resultat inom alla ovanstående områden. RBF utgör en viktig del av både RMNCAH Sharpened Plan och Ugandas nationella hälsofinansieringsstrategi. Projektet har anpassats till det nationella ramverket för RBF och bygger på tidigare erfarenheter från RBF projekt och piloter i Uganda.
Under komponent 2 kommer stöd att ges till MoH med syfte att förbättra hälsosystemet, inklusive tillgång till och distribution av RMNCAH-läkemedel, rekrytering och utbildning av personal, tillhandahållande, distribution och omfördelning av medicinsk utrustning, förbättrad hälsoinfrastruktur och förbättrad kvalitet på vård och uppföljning på distriktsnivå.
Verksamheten under komponent 3 fokuserar på att stödja viktiga institutioner för registrering och statistik (Civil Registration and Vital Statistics - CRVS) samt uppgradering av födelse- och dödsregistrering (Birth and Death Registration - BDR). Förbättrad registrering av födslar och dödsfall är avgörande för att kunna tillhandahålla tillförlitlig data och för att kunna planera effektivt inom hälsosektorn. Aktiviteter innefattar att utveckla en policy, protokoll, manualer och ett system för uppföljning och utvärdering (M&E). Slutligen inkluderar komponent 4 kostnader relaterade till övergripande projektledning med inriktning på alla ovanstående komponenter, inklusive utbildning, kvalitetssäkring, M&E och annat operativt stöd.
Ambassaden har beslutat att öronmärka det svenska bidraget till komponent 1 och 2, då dessa två komponenter bedöms vara mest relevanta för resultatområde 3, förbättrad grundläggande hälsa, samt i linje med ambassadens initiala operationaliseringsplan. Cirka 70 procent av stödet kommer att fördelas till komponent 1 med fokus på RBF och resterande 30 procent kommer att tilldelas komponent 2 för att möjliggöra RBF-programmering genom logistik-, material- och personalresurser.
Utöver stödet för projektet “Uganda Reproductive, Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project” och med anledning av identifierade svagheter kopplat till rättighetsperspektivet, jämställdhet och jämlikhet, planerar ambassaden att avsätta medel för att avropa en konsult som kommer att arbeta tillsammans med Världsbanken och hälsoministeriet med huvudsakligt fokus på uppföljning av integrering av jämställdhet och rättighetsperspektivet. Då det är mycket viktigt att dokumentera lärande och erfarenheter kopplat till projektet pågår dessutom diskussioner med Världsbanken om att avsätta en del (upp till 15 MSEK) av det svenska stödet i syfte att upphandla implementeringsforskning kopplat till utrullningen av RBF i Uganda. I händelse av att parterna når en överenskommelse kommer detta åtagande att specificeras i budget samt i avtal genom införandet av en lämplig skrivning innan avtalstecknandet.

This appraisal forms the basis for a decision on support to the World Bank's "Reproductive, Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project" in Uganda. The Embassy proposes a support of 250 million SEK over a five year period, from 2017 to 2021. The duration of the project is four years and six months, with a total budget of approximately 165 million USD including the Swedish contribution. Out of the total project budget of 165 million USD, 110 million USD is provided through World Bank International Development Association (IDA) loans and 30 million USD is provided by the Global Financing Facility - GFF fund. The project is expected to start being rolled out in June 2017.
In July 2015, Uganda was chosen as one of eight countries to receive support from the Global Financing Facility (GFF) Trust Fund. The GFF in support of the "Every Woman Every Child" movement is a country-driven partnership aiming at accelerating efforts to end preventable maternal, newborn, child and adolescent deaths and improve their health and quality of life, through an integrated health system approach and evidence-based solutions aiming at improving Reproductive, Maternal Newborn, Child and Adolescent Health (RMNCAH) outcomes. In light of the GFF, the Goverment has revised the "2016-2020 RMNCAH Sharpened Plan", highlighting key gaps in service utilization and coverage and establishing priority RMNCAH interventions.
The "Uganda Reproductive, Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project", implemented by the World Bank through the Ministry of Health (MoH) and co-funded by IDA and GFF Trust Fund, will directly contribute to the implementation of the 2016-2020 RMNCAH Sharpened Plan for Uganda. The planned support aims at improving quality of care, access and utilization of essential health services within RMNCAH and scaling up birth and death registration activities in targeted districts in Uganda. The overall project objectives are to:
a) improve utilization of essential health services with a focus on reproductive, maternal, child and adolescent health services in target districts, and
b) scale-up birth and death registration services
The project consists of four different components: Component 1: Results-Based Financing (RBF) for Primary Health Care Services (IDA 43 MUSD, GFF 25 MUSD, Swedish funding 17.5 MUSD) Component 2: Strengthen Health Systems to Deliver RMNCAH Services (IDA 54.5 MUSD, Swedish funding 7.5 MUSD) Component 3: Strengthen Capacity to Scale-up Delivery of Births and Death Registration Services (IDA 5 MUSD, GFF 5 MUSD) Component 4: Enhance Institutional Capacity to Manage Project Supported Activities (IDA 7.5 MUSD)
The specific objective of Component 1, which stands for the largest part of the project budget, is to scale-up and institutionalize RBF with a focus on RMNCAH services. The RBF-package comprises of RMNCAH interventions at facility level III and IV, including Village Health Teams (VHT) and focusing on Ante-Natal Care (ANC), safe delivery, comprehensive emergency obstetric care, essential newborn and postnatal care services, post-abortion care, family planning and community-based RMNCAH services including nutrition, prevention and treatment of common childhood diseases and provision of adolescent health services. RBF payments will be made against verified outputs within all the above areas. RBF is part of the RMNCAH Sharpened Plan as well as Uganda's National Health Financing Strategy and the intervention is aligned with the national RBF Framework and builds on previous RBF experience and pilots in Uganda.
Under Component 2, support will be provided to the MoH to address the most critical bottlenecks to RMNCAH service delivery, focusing on improving availability of essential RMNCAH drugs and supplies, recruitment and training of staff, providing, distributing and redistributing medical equipment, improving health infrastructure and improving quality of care and supervision at district level.
Activities under Component 3 aim at supporting key Civil Registration and Vital Statistics (CRVS) institutions in scaling up Birth and Death Registration (BDR) services. This is crucial for addressing inequalities in service delivery and for providing more reliable data to assist in broader health planning and activities includes developing a policy, protocols, manuals and a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) system. Lastly, Component 4 includes costs related to overall project management focusing on all the above components, including training, safeguards, M&E and other operational issues.
The Embassy has decided to earmark it's funding to Component 1 and 2, being the two most relevant components for results area 3 - improved basic health, also following the Embassy's initial operationalization plan. Approximately 70 percent of the funding will be allocated to Component 1, focusing on RBF, and the remaining 30 percent will be allocated to Component 2, providing logistic, material as well as Human Resources (HR) support to enable RBF-programming.
In addition to providing financial support for the “Uganda Reproductive, Maternal and Child Health Services Improvement Project” and to address perceived weaknesses related to gender and the rights perspective, the Embassy plans to allocate funding to procure a consultant that will work with the project organisation focusing primarily on monitoring the integration of gender equality and Human Rights Based Approach (HRBA) for health issues. Furthermore, as it will be very important to document learnings and experiences, the Embassy is engaged in discussions with the World Bank to allocate a proportion (up to 15 MSEK) of the Swedish contribution towards procuring implementation research regarding RBF in Uganda. In the event that the parties will find an agreement, this commitment will be specified in the budget with appropriate wording inserted into the agreement prior to signature.

3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

3.c - Substantially increase health financing and the recruitment, development, training and retention of the health workforce in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing States.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

description.narrative: The analysis below is based on the annual progress report for FY 2019/20 and Sida's follow-up since the last conclusion on performance (PO handover in July 2019), including participation in four WB monitoring missions. As noted in all previous documentation, the project was approved on August 4th 2016, but only became effective on May 26th 2017. Even so, subsequent delays hampered project implementation further, resulting in almost a full year lost. Implementation had progressed somewhat by the time of the mid-term review mission (MTR) in October 2019, but the levels of disbursement to the MoH and fund utilization on their part were still very low. Following the MTR there have however been significant improvements which can be seen in the more than doubled disbursement rate from 28% at the MTR to about 59% by October 30, 2020. More importantly the fund utilization by the MoH has also increased significantly from 6% in June 2019 to 55% by October 2020. Since the MTR there have been three additional monitoring missions, in February, June and October 2020. Most of the agreed actions have been implemented and the restructuring proposed at the MTR is being finalized with the main element being an extension of the closing date of the project from June 30, 2021 to December 31, 2022. The extension is approved by the Embassy and in its final stages of WB approval. It is expected to enable the completion of all planned activities under the project, including the Operational Research Program (OR), and the achievement of the development objectives. This is also the assessment presented in the aide memoire from the most recent monitoring mission in October 2020: "If the current pace of project implementation is sustained, the PDOs are likely to be achieved. Presently, three of the six PDO indicators have met their annual targets and are on track to meet their end line targets [(i) births attended by skilled health personnel; (ii) pregnant women who received two doses of IPT2 for malaria; (iii) children under one year immunized with the third dose of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine]. However, there has been limited progress on the remaining three PDO indicators (i.e. family planning, birth, and death registration) and these can only be met with increased effort from the MoH and NIRA." COVID-19The pandemic has clearly posed a significant hurdle to project implementation with the attention of the health sector and the entire government focused on COVID-19 at the expense of other essential health services. Consequently, the uptake of RMNCAH services under the project through the results-based financing scheme has been negatively affected. While performance on the RBF-incentivized indicators is still above baseline, performance reduced over the period April-June 2020 due to the pandemic. Relatedly, procurement of firms to undertake civil works for 81 maternity units and field work for the operational research program were also disrupted and construction is yet to commence. Summary of key results and current implementation status Component 1: Results-based financing for primary health care servicesBy the end of financial year 2019/20, the project had rolled out RBF to 131 of the 135 districts in the country, covering 1,249 health centres and 67 hospitals (56 general hospitals, 10 regional referral hospitals and 1 national referral hospital [Kawempe]). The RBF program now covers a population of about 40.1 million or 98 percent of the total population of Uganda. Of the enrolled facilities, 84% are public, and 16% private non-for-profit. Analysis of performance on key health indicators between 2018/19 and 2019/20 shows improvements in several indicators: - the proportion of pregnant women attending antenatal care within the 1st trimester increased by 35%- use of short-term family planning methods increased by 28%- use of long-term family planning methods rose by 24%- postnatal care within six days and at six weeks improved by 18% However, there was no improvement in the number of skilled deliveries by qualified health personnel while there were minimal gains in the number of maternity C-sections (1%), IPT2 (3%), fully immunized children less than one year (5%), and antenatal care fourth visit (6%). It is also worth noting that performance on all RBF incentivized indicators (except for short-term family planning) declined between April and June 2020 due to the pandemic. Despite the generally positive findings, performance at some of the health facilities was poor. This could be attributed to inadequate supervision and technical support by officials at the MoH headquarters to the districts, and by the district health teams to the health facilities. Furthermore, some health facilities spent funds on low priority areas while others invested less than 60% of the RBF-resources on service delivery so while the incentivization increases output, there could be improvements in the way the funds are used. This was raised by the Embassy in the most recent mission as an issue to follow more closely. Clearly, supportive supervision visits to facilities need to increase although a challenge during COVID-19. Delayed verification of results at some of the health facilities, and late submission of RBF invoices by the districts to the MoH headquarters also contributed to delayed disbursement of RBF-funds. To address these challenges, the WB and the MoH have agreed to: (i) ensure continuity of service provision under the RBF through the adoption of a streamlined verification process; (ii) identify the low performing health facilities and districts and provide targeted support supervision on clinical care and quality of care; and (iii) finalize digitalization of the RBF data transmission, invoicing, and visualization system. Component 2: Strengthen Health Systems to Deliver RMNCAH ServicesThis component consists of five sub-components of which the Embassy funds target three (in bold): (i) improving availability of essential drugs and supplies, (ii) improving availability and management of the health workforce, (iii) improving availability and functionality of medical equipment in health facilities, (iv) improving health infrastructure at Primary Health Care (PHC) facilities, and (v) improving quality of care and supervision. Overall, the component continues to underperform with only sub-components (i) and (ii) progressing satisfactorily. Within those two, procurement and distribution of essential RMNCAH medicines and family planning commodities to health facilities has been done. Furthermore, 692 health professionals were provided scholarships to undertake courses for cadres in short supply including critical and intensive care, anesthesia, and master’s in medicine. By December 2019, about 203 of the 692 students had completed their studies and by May 2020, 144 of the 203 had been deployed. 344 were scheduled to complete their studies by the end of June 2020 but have not yet been able to do so due to the pandemic. Due to its relative success, the program has been expanded by an additional 425 scholarships in Intensive Care Nursing Diploma (400) and Masters in Critical Care Nursing (25). While there has been some progress on the procurement of firms to construct 81 maternity units under sub-component (iii), the October mission found that even with the planned extension of the project’s closing date to December 2022, the additional time may still be inadequate to satisfactorily complete the civil works. Thus, the MoH was advised to further accelerate the procurement process for the civil works, medical equipment and furniture, solar, and water supply systems and a number of other actions were also agreed on between the WB and MoH. The quality of care sub-component (v) has seen mixed progress. While a number of key activities have been implemented, the October mission found that the mentorship program has not yet been launched despite most of the findings from the technical support supervision and Maternal and Perinatal Death Surveillance and Response (MPDSR) revealing capacity gaps in providing obstetric and newborn care services. A number of actions were agreed to address the shortcomings. One of those was included based on the recommendation by Sida's senior policy advisor for Health and SRHR, to document the ongoing senior management-led maternal and newborn quality improvement efforts at Kawempe National Referral Hospital (also supported through the Embassy's COVID-19 cost extension with UNICEF). Adolescent health (ADH) has been emphasized by the Embassy as a key priority since the very initial discussions with the WB and MoH regarding the project. The appraisal noted the lack of integration of gender equality and human rights based approach (HRBA) to health in project documentation and limited focus on adolescents, despite being a targeted group in the project objectives. The Embassy pushed for inclusion of related performance indicators in the results framework but as described in the appraisal this was rejected by the WB for various reasons. Ensuring sufficient attention to these issues was therefore identified as a dialogue issue by the Embassy and it was decided to allocate specific support during the first year of implementation through assigning a consultant under Sida's framework agreement for global health with KIT - Royal Tropical Institute. The specific aim of the consultancy was to provide recommendations for an improved integration of gender equality, equity and the HRBA to health and engagement of adolescents on the level of the health facilities, district level and amongst the governance structure of the project. The consultant undertook two missions - September 2017 and April 2018 - and in the final report provided in-depth recommendations on how the integration of gender equality/equity, HRBA and adolescent health could be further improved. The MoH, the WB and the Embassy had extensive discussions around which recommendations to take onboard but never concluded on concrete actions to take. By the time of the last handover between POs at the Embassy (August 2019) there was however an expectation that the focus on these issues in dialogue and follow-up until then would lead to increased focus over time, but this was at least not initially the case. Following the February 2020 mission, the WB even "threatened" to cancel ADH activities completely due to the lack of prioritization and attention by MoH. Fortunately pace picked up and in 2020, in spite of the pandemic, a number of interventions were carried out aimed at addressing the high rates of teenage pregnancy and other sexual, reproductive, and life skills challenges in the project areas. These include engaging cultural leaders on adolescent health and social behavior change for disease prevention, training of master trainers on adolescent health, on-site mentorship and training of service providers in adolescent health. The policy environment is not very conducive however. ADH is sensitive materia and several related policies, strategies and implementation guidlines have been severely delayed which hampers progress in some areas. Given that the pandemic is disproportionately affecting adolescents, it is however even more important now to ensure that ADH is given the attention it deserves. The Embassy therefore took the initiative (Nov 2020) to an informal discussion with MoH and the WB to better understand progress and priorities going forward. The meeting was very useful as it became evident that a lot of things had actually progressed although poorly captured in the formal reports. Therefore the MoH were tasked to submit a separate report specifically on ADH to showcase what has been done. Further, in light of the restructuring, the ADH activities in the workplan will be revised and WB and the Embassy will have the opportunity review and influence the proposed changes by MoH. Operational Research ProgramThe OR program has two objectives: (i) to assist Uganda in generating practical and actionable evidence for RMNCAH implementation; and (ii) to further strengthen the capacity of Ugandan researchers in operational research. Findings generated through the OR program will be used to inform the implementation of RMNCAH programs in the health sector including the revision of the RMNCAH Investment Case for Uganda. As of June 30, 2020, the program had disbursed US$559,474.82. Four Advisory Committee meetings have been convened during the FY 2019/20 with participation by the Embassy's Senior Research Advisor. OR implementation has been considerably delayed by COVID-19 as it halted the ability of researchers to conduct field work which was planned to commence in April 2020. To adjust, the WB and Makerere School of Public Health and the advisory committee agreed on the use of virtual methods for engaging with key informants and in-depth interviews as an interim measure. Research activities have now resumed with 12 of 12 studies approved by the institutional review board and having initiated remote field data collection. Draft reports from the first phase are due by December 31, 2020. A second phase of data collection (hopefully physical) is envisioned for a subset of the studies in early 2021. In September 2020, the WB proposed that the Embassy should support the update of Uganda’s Sharpened Plan through the current resources available through the OR programe. The proposition was in turn based on a request from the MoH to the WB. The rationale as presented by the WB was to strengthen the linkage between the OR programe and the ongoing RMNCAH policy dialogue. It would also ensure a stronger a targeted contribution by the Embassy to the update of the Sharpened Plan. The estimated cost is US$ 20-30,000 which pays for a technical consultant to update the plan, building upon the work that had already been initiated by the MoH including any early findings from the OR program. Following some clarifications, the request was approved by the Embassy. WB reportingWhile formally in line with the agreement requirement, Sida's overall assessment of the most recent annual report was that it is too output focused and lacks depth in analysis. Written feedback was provided to the WB on this and other concerns such as delayed reporting for the third consecutive year, and was followed up by a meeting on 19 October. In their response they argued that they cannot and should not attribute change in the quantitative indicators, to the implementation of the project since there are so many other factors contributing and that the only way to do that is through "expensive impact evaluations". The inability to go to the field due to COVID-19 was also mentioned as a constraint for providing a more qualitative assessment of progress made. A more valid argument was that aside from the initial 28 districts, the remaining ones have only been on RBF for a short period of time. The Embassy maintained that the WB has to be able to better present it's own assessment of how the project is progressing beyond quantitative outputs and the level of disbursements, but agreed with some of the constraints raised by the WB. The content and quality of the WB reports will remain as a dialogue issue and the WB will be reminded of the Embassy's expectations on the next report well ahead of the deadline. Financial managementAs a result of the progress in project implementation, the overall disbursement rate by the WB has more than doubled from 28% at the MTR to about 59% by October 30, 2020. The MoH in turn has improved its utilization rate from 6% in June 2019 to 55% by October 2020. The Embassy has disbursed a total of SEK 200 million (USD 22,5 million) to the WB of which a cumulative total of USD 13,6 million had been disbursed to the recipient executed trust fund (RETF, i.e. to MoH) by 30 June 2020. The non-disbursed balance at that time consisted mainly of funding for operational research, the bank executed trust fund (BETF) and (i.e. not supposed to be disbursed) a fund balance of USD 7 million. The seemingly large fund balance was a result of the third payment from Sida (SEK 50m) being expedited in the same month (June). Part of the unspent fund balance consisted of USD 889,702 in undisbursed commitments, which are defined as "[a]mounts committed relate to the amounts yet to be disbursed for active and pending recipient executed grant agreements and the undisbursed balance of bank executed trust funds." Absorption rate by MoHIn the correspondence in May/June regarding the Embassy's third payment, the WB expressed a readiness by MoH to receive the additional funding in order to sustain activities. The financial management section of the annual narrative report however stated that the MoH absorption rate was 44% by 30 June which indicates less urgency. The report also states that US$5,1m out of Sida’s 5,4m payment (SEK 50m) on 23 June 2020 "will be disbursed to the MoH by the end of the fiscal year”. That too indicated that the actual financial need was not there when the call for funds (disbursement request) was submitted, in spite of assurances by the WB. This issue was raised in the written feedback on the report and addressed in a meeting with the WB on 19 October. The response by the WB was that there is a time lag of up to six months from the submission of the call of funds to the Embassy, to the MoH actually receiving the transfer. The reason being that every time the Embassy makes a payment to the WB, they in turn have to amend their agreement with the MoH to reflect the additional funding. The WB can only commit to their implementing partners what is actually in their accounts, i.e. not based on funding committed through an agreement. That process is very time consuming and is the reason for why the WB submits their call for funds even though the MoH absorption of previous payments was only at 44%. The response is deemed adequate but it would have been useful if the WB informed about these time lags when submitting the call for funds.
